title: J. Palsgravii ... Ecphrasis Anglica in Comœdiam Acolasti. title: Ro. vrbis excidium [In verse.]
text: An leue sir! gladios iterum fenfire sepultisj En crura: encp pedes lacerulaceri ora uagamur: , En sparsi cineres:arq* ossa inhonora iacemus: Nulla urna est cineri: Tumulus non ossibus ullu»» At si forma omni/sensu omni/cV luce carente Optatam pius ad uitam reuocaueris urbem/ V ma dabit cineri Tumulum/dabit ossibus Vrn£. Da uita/extincta est pater: eV quæ maxima quonda; Quæ Deaterrarumfueratmunc ultima rerumest, Reddeanimam/essolitus patencV potes oia solus. Si nimis hoc/sedeatcp tuæ non parcere Romæ: Nee dare poscenti ueniammitamqj roganti: Saltern urbis( si quod reliquum) defende cadauer: Hoc quoq. si nimium:statcp ipsos sterneremuros; Parce tuis saltern Templis /Templisqj tuorum. Non moueant(esto)totmstiafata Quiritum: Nonue Patrum captus princeps.captusqj senatus: No urbis lacemm/exangue/arqj informe cadauer: Non Tempbs armenra boum/er stabulatia equoi)£ Cur te non tangant sparfe,/& sine nomine Diuura Relhquiæi spoliatæ auro/& sine honore iacentesS Cur toleres prædam esse tuis tua sacra mamplisi (Si mhos Calabros/hos Cimbros/hosq. Brigatesi Esse tuos: hosq. esse tuos fas dicere Iberos. title: The Poeticall Essayes of Sam. Danyel. Newly corrected and augmented [Containing 'The First Fowre Bookes of the Civile Wars,' 'The fyft Booke of the Civill Warres,' 'Musophilus,' 'A Letter from Octavia to Marcus Antonius,' 'The Tragedie of Cleopatra,' and 'The Complaint of Rosamond.']
text: Of Cleopatra. But I will seeke to stay it what I may; I am but one-yet one thatCæfar loues, And 6 if now I could doe more then pray, Then should'st thou know how far affection moues. But what my powre and praier may preuaile, He ioine them both,to hinder thy disgrace: And euen this present day 7 will notfaile To do my best with Cæsar in this case. Tit. And sir,euen now her seise hath letters sent, Imet her messenger as I came hither, With a dispatch as he wo Cæsar went, ; But know not what imports her sending thither. Yet this he toId,how Cleopatra late Was come from sacrifice. How richly clad Was seru'd to dinner in most sumptuous state, With all the brauest ornaments she had. How hauing dyn'd,she writes-and sends away Him straight to Cæsar ',and commanded than All should depart the Tombe,and none to stay But her two maides,& one poore Countryman: 'Dol. Why then I know,she sends t'haue audience now, And means t'expcrience what her state cando: To see if Maiesty will make him bow To what affliction could notmoue him to. And 6,if now she could but bring a view Ofrhatfrefli beauty she in youth possest, (The argument wherewith she ouerthrew . I TTie

title: The Poeticall Essayes of Sam. Danyel. Newly corrected and augmented [Containing 'The First Fowre Bookes of the Civile Wars,' 'The fyft Booke of the Civill Warres,' 'Musophilus,' 'A Letter from Octavia to Marcus Antonius,' 'The Tragedie of Cleopatra,' and 'The Complaint of Rosamond.']
text: Of Cleopatra. The rarestsorme of death in earth below, That euerpitty,glory,wonder gat. (more C^w.what newes bring'st thou, can Egypt yet yeelde ' Of sorrow then it hath? what can it ad de To the already ouerflowing store Of sad affliction, matteryet more sad? Haue we not scene the worst of our calamity? Is there behindyet somethingof distresse Vnseenc,vnknown? Tel if that greater misery There be,that we waile not that which is lesfe. -Tell vs what so it be,and tell at first, For sorrow cuer longs to heare her worst. Nun. Well then,the strangest thing relate I will, That euer eye of mortall man hath scene. I(as you know)eucn fro my youth, haue still Attended on the person ofthe Queene:! And euer in all fortunes good or ill, With her as one of chiefest trust haue beenc. And now in these so great extreamities, That euer could to maicstie befall, I did my best in what 7 could deuise, And lefther not,till now she left vs all. £hor. What is she gone. Hath Cæsar forst her so? Nun. Yea,she is gone,andhath deceiu'd him to. Qsor. What,fledto I n d i A,to go findher sonne? Nun. No,not to I n d i A,but to findher sonne. Chor. why then ther's hope she may her state recoueS I a N«»

title: The Third part of the Countesse of Pembroke's Yvychurch; entituled, Amintas Dale, wherein are the most conceited tales of the Pagan gods in English hexameters, etc
text: The third parte of the firvgling together caufeth thunder and lightning : whereof there bee three kindes. Tbefrft, bright and clear e, of a most wtyiderfrtll piercing and fvbtile nature, melting gold, filver , and braffe in a purfe, the purfe never tutchtjle- firoyir.tr the childe in the mothers wombe,the mother no way hurt, killing and ■ (boy ling a man, his garments not fomuch as fchorched. Thefecond is that which bumeth,andis red : the third is fomewhat moyfl, and bur net h not , but maketh bltckjtnd blew .-which wasth~e caufe that his lightning was called Tri- fulcum. Theyr£gleis his byrde^as being , by report, never tvtcht with thun- der, bvt loc^cih~d^reTr^onth~rbvrning beames of the funne , and is King of birds, as Iupiter // Monarch among the Gods. Among trees, the oake isfacred vnto him : becaufe in olde time, the oake by her ackorns , is faid to have given life andfioode, and Iu piter himfelfe is the author of life. He maried his fifier Juno, fo alfo ca!led,i luuando,of helping. Allcgorically , Iupiter notcth the celssliallandfierie region,Juno the ay rie and inferior ; and becaufe that cele- fliallis immediatly conioynedwith this terrestrially and either of them is light andyeelding, leuis & mobilis) they are called brother and fitter : and fith the celeTtiallby reafon of his heate is the agent, and the inferior becaufe of her moysture the patient or recipient, they be therefore alfo Man and Wife, for without heate andmoysture no procreation. But of Toues mariage it were fitter time to fpeake,when Iuno his Wife comes in place. Now therefore to his Mynions'and louetrichy, which transformed him into fundry fiapes of brute beastt: for this immoderate lust and wantonnes, is not onely beaitlike itfielfie, but maketh them alfo beasts which give themfelues ouer thereunto. For the matter remembredby Damanas, I have heard, that the Phoeni- cians didvfuj/yfiiy/etoArgosinGrccce : and being there on a time, when they hadmadefhew of their marchandife, and diuers women of Argos [among . whxk was alfo Jo daughter to Inachus their King) came thither ofpurpofie to buic; the Phamicians tooke them away all to their fiips, and brought them to /Egypt; where this Io was given in mariage to Ofiris the ts£gyptian King,fiurnamcdJupher Aumon^ Diodorus Siculus maketh mention : and Io her fie If e was .afterwards among them honored for a goddeffe, by the name c/Ifis. zyind becaufe the sA:gyptians,in refpett ofhufbandrie, did with d:- vine feruice and ceremonies honor a Cow , thereupon the fable tooke his grottnd,that Io being flolne by Iupiter, was trans formed to a Cow. The im- preffwn of a Cowes hoofe , refembleth a greeke a with an i in the middle : whereupon it is fitid, that Io wit h her f do e wrote her name on the banlee of her fathers irooke. Natalis Comes maketh this ethicall moraliz,ation of it. The c,elestiall and heavenly power in CMan,called reafon orvnderstandiwr, figured by Mcrcurius, dothjnaderate,p.tcifie+_Agd_jempe^ .djnate motions and affect tons proceeding from that other facvltie of the mir.de, provoking to wrath and anger. This cholerike and angry parte of mans mixdeasloxgasit resteth, may bee called Argus,fith *tyc fignifuth heauie and
